title: How to Create an Address Book Using Open Office Calc

steps.headline: Right click on column A and select Column Width.
Select columns B and C and enter in the width of 1.49.
Change the width of column D and E to 0.99.
Change the width of column F to 0.59.
Name the columns.
Center the column titles.
steps.description: Do this by selecting A1 to F1 and then clicking on the center alignment, as indicated in the screenshot.

steps.headline: Add the names of some people.
steps.description: The example ones are fictitious names and/or addresses.

steps.headline: Format the zip code column.
Create a second page.
steps.description: To know how to place the second page properly, click on the preview icon.

steps.headline: Click on the Preview icon again.
steps.description: Look closely at your spreadsheet. You will see some slightly darker and thicker lines. Those are the edges of the printed page.

steps.headline: Select and copy (CTRL C) the title of the columns in A1 to F1 and paste at the top of the second page.
Save as Address_Book or whatever is appropriate for your purposes.
Register your Address Book spreadsheet as a data source.
steps.description: You need to do that so the program that will be accessing the data (Writer, Impress, Calc) will know where to look.

steps.headline: Assign the fields in the spreadsheet.
steps.description: This makes it so when the program looks for a name, it finds it.

tyn: OpenOffice Calc on your computer or electronic device
text:
Open a new, blank spreadsheet. Right click on column A and select Column Width. Enter in 1.19. Select columns B and C and enter in the width of 1.49. Change the width of column D and E to 0.99. Change the width of column F to 0.59. Name the columns. Change A1 to F1 to the following: First Name{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e4/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-6Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e4/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-6Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

The example ones are fictitious names and/or addresses. Format the zip code column. You will notice that the zip with the leading zero is not showing the zero. Right click on the F column and then select Format Cells...{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/16/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/16/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Select the Numbers tab. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/0c/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Select Number under the Category section. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f2/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/f2/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Under Format, click General. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/15/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet4.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet4.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/1/15/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet4.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} In the leading zeros box, change the number 1 to 5{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/56/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet5.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet5.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/5/56/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet5.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} This is how everything should look. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/04/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet6.jpg/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/04/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Create a second page. To know how to place the second page properly, click on the preview icon. Click on the Preview icon again. Look closely at your spreadsheet. You will see some slightly darker and thicker lines. Those are the edges of the printed page. Select and copy (CTRL C) the title of the columns in A1 to F1 and paste at the top of the second page. Save as Address_Book or whatever is appropriate for your purposes. Register your Address Book spreadsheet as a data source. You need to do that so the program that will be accessing the data (Writer, Impress, Calc) will know where to look. Assign the fields in the spreadsheet. This makes it so when the program looks for a name, it finds it.

Right click on column A and select Column Width.
Enter in 1.19.
Select columns B and C and enter in the width of 1.49.
Change the width of column D and E to 0.99.
Change the width of column F to 0.59.
Name the columns.

Add the names of some people.
The example ones are fictitious names and/or addresses.
Format the zip code column.
You will notice that the zip with the leading zero is not showing the zero.

Right click on the F column and then select Format Cells...{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/16\/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/1\/16\/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0c\/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/0c\/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/04\/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet6.jpg\/v4-460px-Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet6.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/04\/Create-an-Address-Book-Using-Open-Office-Calc-Step-9Bullet6.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":342,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":565.8241758241758,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Create a second page.
To know how to place the second page properly, click on the preview icon.
Click on the Preview icon again.
Look closely at your spreadsheet.
You will see some slightly darker and thicker lines.
Those are the edges of the printed page.
Select and copy (CTRL C) the title of the columns in A1 to F1 and paste at the top of the second page.
Save as Address_Book or whatever is appropriate for your purposes.
Register your Address Book spreadsheet as a data source.
You need to do that so the program that will be accessing the data (Writer, Impress, Calc) will know where to look.
Assign the fields in the spreadsheet.
This makes it so when the program looks for a name, it finds it.
